Not actually, Martin. My memories pretty much stop with the Quaker Oats box.

Perhaps it's just as well I didn't go into radio electronics.
What makes you say the writer is self-absorbed? And by the way, South Beach would be my personal idea of hell, second only perhaps to a three-day weekend at the Mall of America.

Mother, daughter, and hotel--all need work. However, it might have been a good idea to talk with a travel agent as someone else posted or at least consult some travel guidebooks, make some reservations, and perhaps focus more on what the daughter might want to do. I was surprised the writer had done so little research or preparation ahead of time. Bad attitudes don't help either, especially in people as self-absorbed as these two seem to be. A few hours in South Beach is a hoot for most folks, and Miami has many truly great restaurants. A real downer of an article.

The opening sentence BTW is pretty mean and nasty. I sincerely hope these two get happier come summer.

What he also failed to mention is the cheapest seat is now $50 or more.  The leveling experience baseball used to be, what we think about when we think of great baseball, is not a choice to most Americans.  What your comment fails to take into account is that choice, or rather the lack of it creeps up the income level.  One day, you too will be priced out of your seat.

Good points, Dave, but Bryan is missing Friedman's key point, which I humbly offer to restate:

When everything has a price, nothing has a value.

It is such a pity! Sir, your decision to write in sentence fragments, has, alas, made your post incomprehensible until the very end, where you seem to believe that either "the government" or Harvard University wants to limit your seat choice in a football stadium.

Harvard likely does not care where you sit, or even if you attend. Oddly enough, neither do the taxpayers or the government, even though taxpayers have purchased most of the football stadiums in America . . .

So now we are encouraged, since "it does require that citizens share in a common life"; why, and by whom and for what ultimate purpose ? Should we decline and simply carry on with our right to free association, to choose our own way, our friends, our own careers and social milieu in which we feel free and comfortable, will we then be forced through the medium of an all knowing big brother to comply ?

That over reach from either philosophers, government, or religion into the outstanding free choice society which we inhabit in the US; where tolerance has steadily made progress to a point which would have astounded our fathers, much less our forefathers, feels compelled to instruct me, a free and law abiding citizen, what standard of civic practice I should follow ? With all due respect to your freedom Professor to hold such views in a free society, and the concurrence of Mr Friedman, I decline your instruction as to where I sit in a stadium or with whom I may, or may not, associate.

Professor Sandel sees signs of a bad trend, in his opinion. What he fails to see is that the encroachment of the market into sports for example is also clearly seen by the consumer; it does not require a "renowned Harvard Professor" to inform the people of the globe that a steady growth of commercial activity and extreme marketing exists world wide, most especially in the biggest sport in the world, football, known as soccer in the US. If it discomforts you, ignore it. Tolerate difference.

Hey, did somebody mention Groucho?

Happy birthday, Yogi!

Yogi is like his contemporary Groucho, two honest to goodness entertainers with once in lifetime talent...God Bless Yogi!
As a youngster in Boston I sat in the bleachers watching as Yogi hit home runs from both sides of the plate in a tight game to beat a strong Red Sox team at home. I was amazed at how small and yet powerful he was up close...More amazing is his WWII record, part of the D-Day invasion force in 1944, helluva guy even as a Yankee I love him for what he accomplished. An Ikon in his time, Happy Birthday Mr. Berra and many more!

This rather poignant story is less a commentary on the mother-daughter travel relationship, than on a  disappointing, overpriced, pretentious  place to stay. Given the myriad problems with the resort, it was inevitable that the author would have a negative experience, no matter who'd have accompanied her.

There were actually four proper names crossing in the left-center if you consider 64D. I knew Jason Giambi, Paul Reiser and Samuel Morse, the Morse code co-inventor, so it wasn't so bad. RADNOR and OMBRE (never heard of) filled themselves.

Hi Dr. W,

There's really no hard and fast rule, as far as I know.

Most constructors try to distribute proper names to make things as fair as possible, but it's tough to tell in advance what people will know and what they won't know. Everyone comes to a puzzle with different references and amounts of pop culture knowledge.

I had some difficulties there too, since I never heard of RADNOR, GIAMBI, or ANI.  It was also hard to dig REISER out of the depths of memory, since I didn't watch that show.  It became mostly filling in with the only letters that seemed to work.

Fun solve except for a multi-natick for me at left central, leaving me with a major DNF there before doing the lookup. In that area three proper names cross -- two D and one A -- which I knew none of, causing me to mess up 75A as well. I seem to recall a NYT "crossword rule" to the effect that that was npt supposed to happen. (Deb?)

Anyway, a better title for the puzzle might have been "Indeed". For "In D'd."

"Just hours after Mr. Obama tried to lead the nation forward, the House Armed Services Committee was turning the clock back. On a 37-to-24 party-line vote, the committee approved an amendment to the annual military budget bill that would bar the use of a “military installation or other property owned or rented by, or otherwise under the jurisdiction or control of the Department of Defense” for a same-sex marriage or “marriage-like ceremony.”

It is hard to imagine how anyone can see this as anything but blatant discrimination.
Flirting isn't deception?  Hm!

I read that book as well. It was amazing.

I feel as though politics are owned by the rich corporations as well....not the candidates themselves, but the parties they align with. Liberal vs. conservative. I only wish they would just sell the naming rights to each candidate, then we would know what corporation we were endorsing with our vote. And that is probably why Ron Paul gets the short shift...no one owns him.
Oh, for the love of money.  Ridiculous.
Yes we did, and ANTSY yesterday (getANTSY), and SKIPROPE (sorry that was 'jump rope').
Didn't we have Cary ELWES this past Friday too?  And SPIEL not much earlier than that?
She was awesome.

Yeah, Ross, repressive social legislation is simply avoiding facing the economic needs of the country. GOP has no answers to the economy so go after weak social program minds. How many minds have been wasted fighting over social issue. Too many and it never stops.
How soon they forget! How little they know!

Exactly. The amount of attention on social issues is not that large on the part of Obama. What attention is being paid is thoroughly justified. Conservatives love to downplay their actions on social issues as "side issues" - and then casually ram through or thwart legislation that has the effect of adding misery or repression in real people's lives.

Right-wing rich people and their apoplogists don't care if abortion is safe and legal, because they can always send their wives, daughters and mistresses to places where it is. In their network of gated communities, they can just ignore children suffering in poverty and invent stories about how the experience of hardship will build their character. They dont worry about being bankrupted by medical expenses. And so on.

But this stuff matters. A just society offers more to its least fortunate than insulting lectures on what constitutes appropriate behaviors and values.

So, you set the house on fire and then complain that all your neighbor talks about is the need for fire hydrants.

Given the very slow recovery and the continued suffering of millions of unemployed Americans, it is contrary to historical trends for the incumbent president to be doing as well as President Obama is doing in the polls. A primary reason is the insanity of the Republicans with all their repressive social legislation. Pointing out that insanity is a good Democratic campaign strategy.

But, for you to argue that President Obama is primarily talking about the social issues requires that you ignore nearly everything he says. You are listening to his speeches, aren't you?

I like Joe Biden.  A little bit of unscripted heart felt honesty is refreshing in a politician. Yes, compare the stats and see how we always spend more and go backwards under a Republican regime. President Obama has been left with a big fire to put out, and not much water to do it with.
Spot on, Mr. Barrett.  I only hope we can see debates of substance about the economy between now and November.

When Obama came into office, the U.S., and indeed the world economy, were perched at the edge of an abyss that some of us feared would be worse than the Great Depression. That Obama has succeeded to the extent that he has in the face of Republican intransigence and obstruction is a near miracle. The people who set this fire are now the ones who subscribe to the same solutions e.g. wanton and extreme deregulation, that got us there in the first place.

You have overturned the hive of honeybees this morning, Ross, which will no doubt garner you some wet noodle lashings before the end of this cycle. I have to admire you since dealing with the current news cycle takes a strong man since that full acre of bee hives which the VP, Joe Biden, kicked over last weekend, in his inimitable manner consistent with his long experience of making hash out of rare roast beef, which forced the President to stop evolving and to come out in the cold light of day and take a stand. No doubt Joe Biden got an appropriate wet noodle lashing. The Chicago guys have shown little tolerance for the Delaware small town bull in yet another china shop. Joe simply cannot get it right; pardon me; left.

Just in case the facts have not registered on a single reading of your column, Ross, it is all about the economy. Without jobs for the unemployed who are part of the head count, or those who have exhausted their unemployment and have magically been erased from the statistical count, and the hordes of three years now of unemployed college graduates, along with millions who are high school grads, or worse still, the unknown millions of unemployed high school dropouts, and then the demobilized newly returned veterans. How to explain the catastrophe in the jobs field to the afflicted who bear the brunt of the burden, whose young hopes have been dashed as they look to a future which will try their souls, their patience, and the bright hopes they had.

Replacing an encroaching market by an encroaching state is jumping from the frying pan into the fire. Intellectuals, and many others, prefer the State fire to the Market-based frying pan because they think they can control the State, but by an large out of control markets are safer for people than an out of control state. A good book on this subject is Kahan, Mind vs. Money: Thw Ware Between Intellectuals and Capitalism.

Sandel's and Friedman's point is that society is comprised of more than a private for-profit economy and a public-sector state. It is the diminished sphere of civil society they are highlighting as a worrisome trend. This is the domain in which people interact for reasons other than monetary gain -- for fun, to lend a helping hand, to meet social needs, and to learn from one another. This is why museums, parks and art galleries, while they provide a service and collect entry fees, are also publicly funded.

When taxation is widely seen as a wasteful drain on as 'taxpayers' without the participatory benefits of 'citizenship', then private companies will be invited to sustain impoverished public goods. That's why schools accept donations from pop companies, in return for filling their halls with vending machines disepensing junk food.

An effective state certainly must deliver value for our tax dollars, but it is not solely the state's own institutions we are funding. NGOs need a mix of private and public funds to survive. They may offer a service that people pay for (if they can afford to), but they cannot rely on the marketplace alone to survive and deliver on their mission. We live in a mixed economy; as well as nurturing volunteerism, civil society needs revenues from both 'sides' to flourish.

This is an excellent column and Professor Sandel's book addresses the important question of where the reach of the market should stop.

My belief is that the debate about the appropriate reach of the market economy is one of the key questions of our time. Unlike Professor Sandel, however, I believe that the answers to this question define a critical difference between Republicans and Democrats. Today, many Republicans seek to shrink government through privatization and program cuts, a trend that has been evolving over the past 20-30 years. It is this trend that results in public schools selling naming rights. Democrats, by contrast, are more supportive of public funding and operation of government programs.

More subtly, strong admiration for market competition-- as regularly expressed by Mr. Friedman, for example-- can fuel unhealthy extremes, as reported in this column. It is worth examining not only the successes of the market, but also its failures and its encroachment on civic life and community values, as Mr. Friedman has done in this excellent piece.
I tried ABEND for 27A, but I had to give it up to put in some crosses that themselves later turned out to be wrong.

My mom died from cancer in October of 1997. I was going through infertility treatments at the time. So I was not a mother and I no longer had my mother. Needless to say, Mother's Day the following spring was awful. I don't even think I got out of bed.

Today as I was walking through some stores with my now 13 year old daughter, many clerks said to me and other shoppers (many of whom did not have any kids with them), 'have a happy Mother's Day.' They should probably not do that. Many, many women will certainly not have a happy Mother's Day.

This was an excellent column. Thanks.

For those who are so enamored of living abroad, choose wisely. As an legal immigrant who was born in a socialist leaning, never quite got it right style country, you might find your hopes shaken, from place to place. The austerity programs now so popular in the EU, dictated by the unelected de facto EU CEO, Chancellor Merkel, requiring huge cutbacks in health and education provisions, rates of personal taxation high and headed higher, and a host of intrusive regulatory provisions, imposed by both the country in question and the EU, which make our outstanding United States truly the land of the free, and the home of the brave.

Many Americans champion the "free" benefits in Europe; nothing is free.

If high personal Income Taxes, President Hollande of France now wants a top rate of 75%, a Value Added Tax of 22% in many countries, $10 per US gallon Gas or Diesel, 1.4 to 2.0 Liter engines in tiny light weight cars, and in some countries, high death rates on the highways, you might enjoy the experience. Rationing of health services is another ignored inconvenience, and I will add that Medicare, which I have been blessed to benefit from makes the vaunted European system look paltry by comparison.

Consider carefully, disappointment can be costly.

Having enjoyed fifty years in the US, I for one, would never consider for a moment surrendering the freedoms we enjoy to permanently relocate to Europe.

Janice, your comment touched me particularly today.   I was out dining with my adult son today for Mother's Day.   Like you, I have a wonderful conversational rapport with him and among other interesting subjects, the issue of Romney and his 17-year-old self.    My son is a Special Ed teaching aide (he has just won Teaching Aide of the year in our county).   He told me that the high school students of today think differently than previous generations and have been "evolving" due to foward thinking in the schools and, pardon my pride, it is Mother's Day, my son.   I realize that this depends on the area of the country but it does seem to infiltrate and change.

Dear Mr. Burke, what a strange contrast, gay marriage and murder! I've met many gay couples and they would recoil from violence faster than any heterosexual. I guess it's not in their DNA!

Religious people think they're the center of the universe but insulting god is something people do all the time. In Louisiana they still do it but not as noisily as they do in New York!

My 13 year old and I were talking about gay marriage today and all the press coverage recently surrounding Biden's recent TV interview. Her comment was, "I thought America was the land of the free. Every gay person I have ever met wants to be happy just like anyone else. I guess we are not free here at all. This is really sad."

I could not agree more.
Deadline—Trollery and flame wars sound like intriguing additions to anyone's vocabulary. What do they mean?

Who the heck are you to 'tolerate' anyone? What gives you the right to dictate the definition of love or family to the rest of the world? What business is it of yours which religious and social traditions are followed by other people?

Respect and tolerance, you say, as long as your own beliefs are the law of the land and your worldview is not challenged.

Canada accepted nationwide same sex marriage and as far as I can tell, it has not brought on the collapse of Canadian society nor has it corrupted traditional marriage. Everyone still gets married and has kids at the same rate they did previously.

It's a sad thing that we have ceded our leadership in the world manufacturing, education and, now, tolerance. But we're leading the world in the race to the bottom. People like you, Ed, are just dead weight as the country tries to move forward.
francine said...we're leading the world in the race to the bottom...agreed for different reasons...that is a whole new subject matter.

Then let me clarify it for you, Ed. The Republicans are intent on leading this country in a race to the bottom. Not content to merely deny citizens civil rights, they seek to remove hard-won existing legal protections. As more countries around the world fight for fair and honest elections, Republicans champion voter suppression laws. When multinationals foul our environment, Republicans take the side of corporations over communities and continue to dismantle regulations while fighting new safeguards. While women around the world fight for their rights, Republicans chip away at women's rights at home. When Republicans promised to focus on jobs, no one expected they were about to engage in a campaign of job destruction by firing police, firefighters and teachers while undermining unions and disregarding workers' rights. (And then have the temerity to bemoan persistent unemployment!) While countries around the world embrace education for the future of their economies, Republicans starve every program from Head Start to Pell Grants. Although developed countries around the world ensure the health of their citizens as a matter of public policy, Republicans campaign on dismantling the Affordable Care Act, Medicare, Medicaid, public health grants targeted for poor women.

And that's just a short list, Ed.

Who do you love?...a grade school remark by vice-president Biden concerning same-sex marriage.

The Obama administration is playing with the raw instinctive feelings of our young. Our very young, in some public schools, are being taught the same-sex syndrome...seemingly, not a natural growth, that one would expect since the beginning of man and woman.

If it were (same-sex normality)...it would not have to be taught.

This president is tinkering with the traditional family....the backbone of what makes this country strong. Surely no one knows of the 300 plus million Americans, how many of the gay community there are. We can respect them, tolerate them...but to elevate their style of life to a status of a traditional family life is beyond the norm

Who do you love?...a ridiculous remark...obvious a gay man does not love a woman. Why is that? Can a teacher in lower grade schools explain to the children...why that is? Can a teacher explain to the kids, why the gay community is monolithic. Surely these kids know that without their mother and father...they would not be...nor would they ever have a brother or sister. One can imagine, if the Obama endorsement (same-sex marriage) ever took hold in our country, with 4 more years, the Obama initiative would become the motivator of many in our country...we would become the laughing stock of the world.

Respect and tolerance must be our answer to the gay community, with civil compensation in whatever form...marriage must be rejected.

I cannot agree. Thank you, Joe Biden, for forcing the President to "come out" with his beliefs, sooner than later.

As a gay man, it has made a huge difference to me - in how I see myself and in hope for a future in which sexual orientation will matter as little as eye color. Until now, I never thought that day might come.

Once again, thank you Joe for your support and affection.
Teddy didn't need a teleprompter- it was before TV- he just sat and read it.

Joe Biden didn't stick his foot in his mouth; he spoke from his heart about actual people he cares for.
If you're not gay or lesbian, you know someone who is... in your workplace, church, neighborhood or perhaps even in your own extended family.
Joe Biden is a hero for speaking from his heart without spin or calculation.

VP Joe Biden has doubtless felt some heat since last weekend when he kept his string of unerringly aiming and putting his foot in his mouth, kicking consistent with his many years of unerring practice at being the best that he can be at creating political problems, not only for himself, effortlessly, and this time around including the President as he was still evolving, slowly, even surely, though still forced to come out prematurely, thanks to good old Joe from down Route #202 in Delaware. VP Biden may be in the dog house for some time should the Chicago handlers have their way.

Maureen, you are outstanding when you get riled up and get on the Bully Pulpit, and let them have it, whoever they are. Since President Teddy Roosevelt, few, other than Trueman perhaps, have done that act well. Somehow President Obama does not strike me as being successful, since that two hour speech pattern which Teddy reveled in, pre Teleprompter, could hardly be replicated, since our attention span has shrunken so much, and newspapers do not report verbatim any more.

Welcome back from France and surely you will have another interesting column on your predictions of how President Hollande will become the savior of the EU.
Insightful, Steve...there must be more where that came from.

The author's experience mirrors exactly what my wife and I have found in our travels.  Most resorts and hotels which charge outrageous prices really do very little to justify them.  $20 cocktails, $5 bottled waters, 2 bath towels (and no more), surly attitudes, and indifferent service.  We have had consistently better food and service at upper-mid level accommodations, than at the higher levels.
